The '''2011 Algerian protests''' are a continuing series of protests taking place throughout [[Algeria]] from January 2011 onwards. Causes cited by the protestors include [[unemployment]], the lack of housing, [[food inflation]], [[Political corruption|corruption]], [[freedom of speech]] and poor [[living conditions]]. While localised protests were already commonplace over previous years, simultaneous protests and riots erupted all over the country starting in January 2011. These were quelled by government measures to lower food prices, but were followed by a wave of [[self-immolation]]s, most of them in front of government buildings. Opposition parties then began to hold demonstrations, illegal in Algeria without government permission under the [[State of emergency|State of Emergency]] obtaining since 1992.
The '''2011 Algerian protests''' are a continuing series of protests taking place throughout [[Algeria]] from January 2011 onwards. Causes cited by the protestors include [[unemployment]], the lack of housing, [[food inflation]], [[Political corruption|corruption]], [[freedom of speech]] and poor [[living conditions]]. While localised protests were already commonplace over previous years, simultaneous protests and riots erupted all over the country starting in January 2011. These were quelled by government measures to lower food prices, but were followed by a wave of [[self-immolation]]s, most of them in front of government buildings. Opposition parties then began to hold demonstrations, illegal in Algeria without government permission under the [[State of emergency|State of Emergency]] obtaining since 1992.
